properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warning of potential breaking sea conditions and overwash issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Area on 2020-12-01. An intense low pressure system will generate strong southeasterly winds over the specified areas below. The combination of these winds and the current run of mid-amplitude tidal ranges may produce minor breaking sea conditions along the coast near the following localities on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time). Forillon Park - Gaspé - Percé: 2020-12-01, from 12:00 PM to 04:00 PM. New-Carlisle - Chandler: 2020-12-01, from 12:30 PM to 04:30 PM. Anticosti: 2020-12-01, from 12:00 PM to 04:00 PM. ### Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-01T23:59:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-01T20:44:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3514273429.2020
Area: Chandler area, New Carlisle - Port-Daniel area, Forillon National Park - Gaspé area, Percé area, Natashquan, Chevery, Anticosti
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain at times heavy combined with significant snow melt will continue tonight. Additional rainfall amounts: 10 to 20 mm, except 30 mm in areas of heaviest rain. Location: Northwest New Brunswick. Time span: continuing tonight ending early Wednesday morning. Remarks: Between 15 to 30 mm of rain has already been reported across northwestern New Brunswick by this afternoon. Rain at times heavy will continue tonight giving additional amounts up to 30 mm before rain ends before dawn Wednesday. Mild temperatures accompanying the rain will cause likely melt what remains of the existing snow pack. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-02T11:39:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-01T19:40:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3463678491.2020
Area: Edmundston and Madawaska County, western half of Restigouche County, Campbellton and eastern half of Restigouche County, Grand Falls and Victoria County, Mount Carleton - Renous Highway

properties.Summary:

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected today into Wednesday. Snow, heavy at times, and blowing snow has begun in North Bay and will continue northward this afternoon into early Wednesday. Snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 centimetres are expected before the snow weakens Wednesday afternoon. Falling snow, along with wind gusts up to 70 km/h, will allow for blowing snow to occur and significantly affect visibilities today and tonight. This snowfall is the result of a low pressure system expected to move through eastern Ontario into Quebec today into Wednesday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-02T08:44:40-00:00

properties.Summary:

Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warm, windy, and rainy conditions are expected for the southwest Yukon and northwestern B.C. today and Wednesday. Areas exposed to winds from the southeast could see gusts to 60 km/h today and Wednesday as a powerful storm remains over the Gulf of Alaska. These strong winds will aid in raising temperatures today and maintaining them through Wednesday. Precipitation will start as snow and change to rain as temperatures rise above freezing. Periods of rain are expected to continue through Wednesday with the potential for some areas to see 10 to 30 mm through Wednesday afternoon. These temperatures are 10 to 20 degrees celsius above seasonal normals for this time of year. More seasonal conditions will return on Thursday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-02T10:04:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-01T18:05:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2615157985.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A stalled front is pushing moisture through the Alsek Valley into the Haines Junction area. 24 cm of snow has fallen since last night. Periods of snow will change to rain this afternoon as temperatures climb above freezing. Periods of freezing rain are also possible before this change occurs. The rain will continue through to Wednesday. Significant rainfall combining with the snow on the ground may result in water pooling and localized flooding. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-02T10:17:48-00:00

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major winter storm is expected. A total of 40 to 50 cm of snow followed by 50 to 70 mm of rain is forecast for the Haines Road and South Klondike Highway by Wednesday night as a frontal system stalls over the area. Heavy snow continues today with strong winds giving local blowing snow. 40 to 45 cm of snow fell since last night and an additional 10 to 20 cm is forecast near White Pass and the Haines Road. Temperatures will remain near freezing today. The snow is forecast to change to rain by this evening as the warm airmass pushes through and snow levels rise above 1200 metres. Significant rainfall is forecast tonight through Wednesday with 50 to 70 mm of rain. Heavy snow is forecast to return to Chilkat Pass and White Pass Wednesday night as snow levels drop below pass levels. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-02T10:09:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-01T18:10:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0620607855.2020
Area: Haines Road - Haines Junction to Pleasant Camp, South Klondike Highway - Carcross to White Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

The highest rainfall amounts are expected in the southwest where amounts could reach upwards of 70 mm by Wednesday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow and local blowing snow continues into this evening. An additional 10 to 20 cm of snow is expected, mainly between Sarnia and London. Hazards: 10-20 cm of additional snow Blowing snow Wind gusts to 70 km/h Impacts: Poor visibility in quickly accumulating snow and blowing snow Poor road conditions Worst impacts expected between Sarnia and London Timing: Continuing now through early Wednesday morning 22cm of snow has been reported at London Airport and by a weather spotter in Parkhill so far through this event, however regional RADAR depicts the heaviest snow in a lake enhanced band between Sarnia and London now. Widespread snow will continue across the area, but the bulk of the heavy snow should be focused between Sarnia and London this evening before gradually easing overnight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Multi-day snowfall event continues tonight into early Wednesday. Additional snowfall amounts of 5 cm are possible tonight through Wednesday morning. Motorists should be prepared for winter driving conditions. This snowfall is a result of a strengthening low pressure system expected to move through eastern Ontario into Quebec today into Wednesday. Precipitation associated with this low pressure system is expected to move east of the area Wednesday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing precipitation amounts of 5 millimetres are expected this evening. The freezing rain will change over to rain after midnight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
